story:
With the 5 year anniversary of my life threatening condition fast approaching, I am reaching out to ask for support to cover medical expenses so that I may try to rebuild some semblance of my life. 

My story was featured on CTV news piece several months ago to help spread awareness for my condition; it can be viewed through the following link:

http://www.ctvnews.ca/video?clipId=289587&p...

My name is Jessica-Faye Watters; I am a 25 year old artist living in Ottawa, Ontario. On Thanksgiving 2009 I became ill with bronchitis which soon developed into H1N1. As I'm sure many have heard, it was a brutal flu but what remains lesser known are the long term effects of this illness. I never seemed to get better, in fact I actually grew worse. One by one causes were ruled out; concerns of an eating disorder were even raised, but after seeing 2 therapists these fears were dispelled. After years of specialists, ineffective drugs, tests that were invasive and sometimes quite unpleasant, and even tube feeding after a weight loss of over 120 lbs, it wasn't until the end of 2012 that I was finally diagnosed with a condition known as Gastroparesis.

Simply explained, this is a disorder that slows or stops the movement of food from the stomach to the small intestine. Within our bodies is the vagus nerve that controls the muscles of the stomach that normally contract to break up food and move it through the gastrointestinal tract as well as the hormones and enzymes that helps us digest food. It goes deeper than this, however, also controlling our involuntary functions such as breathing, blood pressure, swallowing and heart rate. Even our emotions are affected by it. Gastroparesis occurs when that nerve becomes damaged by injury/illness and the stomach muscles cease to contract normally. This slows or all together stops movement of food from the stomach to the small intestine.

According to a Gastric Emptying Study done Nov 2012 this is how my stomach empties compared to an average person.

  •   1 hr normal: 37-90% mine: 99%
  •   2 hr normal: 30-60% mine : 88%
  •   3 hr normal: 0-30% mine: 54%
  •   4 hr normal: 0-10% mine: 44%

My day to day life includes but isn't always limited to the following:

  •   Constant abdominal pain
  •   Constant Nausea
  •   Vomiting (inability to keep ANY food down or even small bits of fluids at times)
  •   Constipation (which can switch to diarrhea)
  •   Low Potassium, Magnesium, & Iron
  •   Muscle aches and weakness
  •   Hypersensitivity (to both touch and temperature)
  •   Insomnia
  •   Dehydration
  •   Abdominal Bloating
  •   Stomach Dissention
  •   Hair loss
  •   Dry Skin
  •   Anxiety
  •   Depression

Even with a diagnosis I still find myself in medical limbo. Since Gastroparesis has no known cure at this time and without earlier identification I have become too weak to even take the medication that would normally be prescribed for this. I was given a trial of Metoclopramide, Domperidone and Erythromycin (3 of the leading names in Gastroparesis treatment) but after having bad side effects from all, the last even landing me in ER I was told I could no longer even attempt them due to the potential of heart damage it could cause. This is due to having also developed chronic low potassium or Hypokalemia. the deterioration has also caused me to develop Fibromyalgia, which adds more pain to certain points in my body.

Different procedures exist to try and combat this condition but my specialist has advised me to keep clear of them, saying that his other patients have actually gotten worse after having undergone them and while tube feeding is an option my blood work and state of mind are healthier by my current regiment of trying to eat by mouth, even though I can't keep it down. Come November, I will be attempting the Erythromycin once again; I pray my body will be able to benefit from it.

More and more I see news of fellow GPers passing away and I am left scared and longing for my old self. I want to be there for the people I love and who have supported me throughout this nightmare. I can't begin to describe the expenses that have been exhausted,  financially and emotionally. One by one I lost the dreams I'd struggled to achieve. I am passionate about expressing myself through my art, whether it be by hand, computer or photography; I have a certificate in Pre-animation/Illustration had been transitioning from Algonquin College's Animation program to a winter intake course, with plans to apply to Photography when my health became too weak to attend school. I now carry a hefty student debt, caused by medical expenses rather than education. With the aid of my loving parents I took a 6 month leave from work at Coliseum Ottawa Theater until the costs were too great. I worked in a limited position at the theater for another year only to have my health decline faster. It wasn't until my doctor firmly advised me to do so that I had to leave the job I loved. I am on Disability now but have discovered many limitations with what the program can actually provide. While full recovery may seem a distant dream I want to continue living my life and being a part of others.

For day to day living, I must constantly keep a hefty supply of vitamins and Gatorade as well as use Restorlax 1-2 daily to function properly. These are items that are not considered medical, yet I can't live without and take their toll financially. There are different alternative measures and therapies that I would like to attempt to try and stimulate healing, not only physically but emotionally as well, but I am unable to afford them at this time. There is also medical equipment to help ease the day to day symptoms, such as a hospital bed since I am unable to lift my body some days due to the deterioration, enamel restoration for my teeth (the amount of vomiting has left the nerves exposed), tools to help food preparation since my energy is limited and even just day to day needs like high calorie foods to gain weight and warm clothing for the upcoming Winter since I am now so sensitive to the temperature. Additional funds above the target goal would be greatly appreciated to realistically cover what I need. I believe if I could at least build up my strength and get my weight up, I can survive this ordeal.

Any support would be greatly appreciated at this time. Gastroparesis is considered an invisible disease, and even those who are suffering the worse do not always appear sick to the people around them. Many have lost their battle and I refuse to lose mine!

I am working to spread awareness, creating content that can be found here:

It's Not Easy Being Green

story:
Holiday Greeting from Stable Connections                    

This past year was a challenging but a rewarding one for Stable Connections. We were busy with our Summer Equine Assisted Programs, which concentrate on providing psychosocial therapy for at-risk youth groups, our Therapeutic Riding/Horsemanship Program and private psychotherapy sessions. It was incredibility rewarding to see the change in all of our students over the course of the summer.

We rolled into September offering private sessions and because of the increased need; we offered a fall Equine Assisted Psychotherapy group program. It quickly became clear in order to meet the growing need for our services, and offer programming year round we need to cover our program arena so we can continue rain or shine. In an effort to meet this goal, we applied for two separate grants but we need additional funds to ensure this dream becomes a reality.

During the season of giving, I am asking you to become part of the Stable Connections team and help transform lives of individuals that have been either physically or emotionally scarred. With your generous support, we will be able to cover the arena and expand the numbers of clients by providing additional services on a yearly basis.

EXPANSION OF THERAPY ARENA

The business has established solid relationships with the area Mental Health Agencies, but unfortunately due to the weather we have cancelled too many appointments with these clients and consistency is the key to the client’s long term goals.

The existing outdoor arena of 60 ft. x 120 ft. has been made with sand/clay footing for the horses; we have leveled the surrounding ground area and purchased appropriate fencing in order to expand the area to 80 ft. x 140 ft., thus allowing us to treat multiple clients at the same time.

It is imperative that we raise the necessary funds to cover our outdoor program/riding arena to continue our programs even when the weather is inclement. This will be the only indoor riding arena available to serve clients in the northern New Hampshire and Vermont area.

Equine Assisted Psychotherapy and Equine Assisted Learning

These constitute the core programs at Stable Connections.  Our facilitating team includes a licensed mental health therapist, equine specialist and when appropriate, additional qualified specialists. This team approach allows us to provide the highest quality services for our clients.

This type of interactive psychotherapy (EAP) with the horse is conducted on the ground and involves no mounted riding. Whether dealing with issues of addiction, depression, behavioral disorders, and trauma, grief, loss or relationship difficulties, clients have discovered new hope and lasting solutions through our equine assisted psychotherapy program.

Therapeutic Riding  

The goal of our Therapeutic Riding Programs is to teach the basics of horsemanship and riding. We strive for riders to become as independent as possible! Our goal is to increase the client's physical, cognitive, and emotional development by using the gently and rhythmic movement from horseback riding. 

A few of the disabilities we currently treat: Cerebral palsy, low muscle tone, severe learning disabilities, speech or vision impairment, epilepsy, autism, attention deficit disorders, emotional disabilities, Down Syndrome and Rett Syndrome.                                                                                                 

The Community Need

Consistency is the key to overall health for our client base. Whether we are dealing with emotional or physical disabilities, having to cancel appointments due to the weather is disappointing to everyone. This past summer due to the weather, we cancelled twenty-five separate sessions and this past September, ten sessions had to be cancelled.      

Our Goal is to increase our current programming to include programs for the Wounded Warrior Project, double our Therapeutic Riding program and increase our ability to help more at-risk children with behavioral issues. The site has been prepared for the covered arena by leveling the ground surrounding the existing arena. 

Our focus as a business is on wellness and empowerment and I believe that we offer a truly unique program that will help the lives of many people with varied needs. It is because of your commitment to the community that I appeal to you and your organization to help with establishing a year round program facility. A grant from your organization would allow us to meet the needs of so many individuals that desperately need this service.

Taking this unique opportunity to become part of the future of Stable Connections helps us to become the premier Equine Assisted Psychotherapy Program in Vermont and New Hampshire. 

By becoming part of Stable Connections team, you will help transform the lives of individuals that have been either physically or emotionally scarred. With your generous support, we will be able to cover the arena which will allow us to expand the availability of services to our clients.

story:
The Club and the Community

The Nipissing District Tennis Club is a seasonal tennis club in North Bay, Ontario with 6 courts and 246 members in 2013.  The club is owned by Fransua Rachmann and Bobby Ray. 

NDTC is the only tennis club in North Bay that offers a membership, programming, socials, leagues and tournaments.  We also offer tennis lessons for anyone from individual lessons to large school groups. In the summer we offer 8 weeks of summer camps for children between 7 and 17 years old.

Bobby and Fransua only recently took over management of the courts. But the courts have not been resurfaced or properly maintained since 2007.  Of the 6 courts, 3 courts will be dangerous to play on next season.  Since North Bay is in Northern Ontario, it gets a lot of snow in the winter and the club only operate from April to October.  The big fluctuations in temperature causes the courts that were constructed more than 20 years ago to heave and crack.  Short term repairs have been attempted, but to make the courts safe and playable for the future, extensive reconstruction of the courts will have to be done.

Contributors to the NDTC will help us deliver a service to more than 83000 people in North Bay and the Nipissing District.  A big part of the community are First Nations and with updated facilities we will be able to invite school groups and adults from the whole Nipissing District to introduce tennis to them and promote health and fitness.

We would also like to make our facility more wheelchair accessible.  We need to convert part of our gravel parking lot and walkways into paved surface to accommodate wheelchairs.  We also need to convert our washrooms into wheelchair accessible units. Recently there has been a need for wheelchair access to the courts, and we want to meet those needs and also be able to promote wheelchair tennis in Northern Ontario.


Our main goal is to introduce children to the game of tennis, have families play tennis together and to get people more active and fit. We want to break the notion of tennis being a "snobby" or "elite" sport and promote it as an affordable, fun activity for people of any age and all walks of life.

Tennis is one of the few sports where a whole family can play together on one court, children and adults can keep a ball going over the net or play points against each other or parents can help their children practice coordination or hitting the ball.

We offer tennis to people at very reasonable prices and people can even come and try tennis for free since they can borrow racquets and balls from the club at no cost.  We increased our membership from 172 members in the 2012 season (under previous management) to 246 members in 2013 and our next goal is to reach 275 members in 2014, but to make that possible we'll need all 6 courts to be in match play condition.


Fransua and Bobby are the owners of Robert Fransua Inc. a sport management, coaching and event organising company. They became the owners of the Nipissing District Tennis Club in May 2013.

Fransua has more than 15 years of coaching experience and has coached tennis in South Africa, the UK, USA and in the United Arab Emirates and now in Canada. He is one of only 125 coaches in Canada that has a Club Pro 2 Canadian Tennis Professional Association qualification. Fransua also has a Sport Psychology Diploma and a Business Management Diploma.

Bobby Ray is a recent graduate of Nipissing University's Bachelor of Physical and Health Education program. Bobby is also the General Manager of the North Bay Granite Curling Club and volunteers with Sport North Bay and the local Young Professionals Committee.



Why we need funding

Funding is needed for four areas at NDTC:

1) Reconstruction of court 1, 2, 5 and 6.

2 Resurfacing of court 3 and 4

3) Construction of wheelchair accessible walkways and washrooms

4) Promotion and sponsorship of tennis to First Nations

1) Court #1 currently has a crack running down the middle of it that is at certain places more than 2 inches wide and getting deeper with each rain fall. The crack is now spreading to court #2 and is getting to the point where the crack is not just affecting the bounce of the ball when it lands near the crack, but also starts being a tripping hazard to players. In places the crack is wide enough for a tennis shoe to fit into, if someone steps on the edge of this crack he or she might sprain or break an ankle.

$80 000 will go towards demolition, lying a new foundation and then resurfacing of court #1 and #2


Court #5 and #6 are the first courts that were built at the venue in 1960.  The courts were maintained and resurfaced numerous times over the years, but frost and heaving of the foundation has finally rendered these courts unfit for play.  The bumps and holes in the courts make bounces unpredictable and have caused people to trip on the courts. 


The lights on these courts are also outdated, inefficient and currently burned out bulbs that need to be replaced are not accessible. The posts used on these courts are higher than health and safety permit standard equipment to reach.  So a specialized crane will have to be rented every time a light bulb needs to be replaced.  Tennis specific lights with energy efficient bulbs will solve this problem.

It will cost $110 000 to completely dig up these courts and replace the light posts.


2) Court #3 and #4 are currently the only 2 courts that are in decent match playable shape.  But courts should ideally be resurfaced at least every 5 years and the last time that the courts were resurfaced was in 2007. Especially in regions where there are high fluctuations in temperature, keeping court surfaces in good shape seals the upper layers from water penetration.  Any water that seep into hairline cracks will freeze in the winter, expand and cause large fractures and bumps and dips on the court of the same nature as court #5 and #6.

It will cost at least $20000 to resurface these two courts and insure their current condition for another 5 to 8 years

3) Wheelchair accessibility is extremely important to give handicapped people in our region the opportunity to also experience playing tennis.  It is also important to us that our facility be accessible to handicapped spectators or family and friends of players.

We have some walkways at the club at the moment and we also have a ramp that leads into our clubhouse.  But we have a gravel parking lot and a crushed rock path at one entrance and a grass patch at the other entrance that lead up to the walkways that make it extremely difficult for a wheelchair to reach the walkways.

Our small washroom has also not been updated since the club has been established on the property in the 80's.  We have one unisex washroom with a toilet and a sink in a 5'x4' space.  We do have some space to expand and we need to convert some of our storage space into a larger washroom facility that is accessible for wheelchairs and provide a better looking and more comfortable washroom facility to our members and visitors to the club.

Paving a small part of our parking lot will cost $6000 and expanding and updating the washroom will cost $12000

4) Providing services to First Nations in our area has been a long term goal for our company.  We have the opportunity to bring children to our facility and introduce them to tennis.  We also have the chance then to identify First Nation children with the drive and talent that might be interested in continuing lessons at the club and have the opportunity to compete in matches and tournaments at the club and in tournaments in Ontario.

We also would like to market tennis to First Nations families as a fun activity that they can enjoy together to promote family values, fitness and recreation.

With $12000 we'll be able to promote the sport, pay for transport to and from the club. and pay for lessons and equipment for at least two seasons at NDTC.   


Plan B

If we don't get the desired amount of funding, we have to concentrate on the most important issues of the club in the following order.

<$16 000 - The large crack on court #1 can get a short term fix by just concentrating on the crack itself and it can be sealed very cheaply at the beginning of each season. This will still cause an uneven bounce if balls do bounce anywhere along the fixed line, but the risk of people tripping and falling on the court is reduced. 

>$16 000 -  The other option is getting a tennis specific contractor to fix the crack.  The fix is guaranteed for 5 years and will cost more than $16000. 

>$30 000 The next issue is fixing and resurfacing court #2.

>$60 000 Resurfacing court #3 and #4. 

This will guarantee the club has at least 4 new courts and the future of the club will be secure. The club will be able to pay for maintenance and resurfacing after every 5 years from membership and programming fees. Court #5 and #6 might need to be scrapped completely and not be used for tennis because of the tripping hazards on the court. The membership of the club might have to be capped at 250 members to accommodate all the players.  We will also not be able to host summer tennis camps on the courts since camps take up 2 courts in the summer for 8 weeks while members play at the same time on the other 4 courts.

>$80 000) Wheelchair accessible parking lot, walkways and washrooms will be constructed

>$100 000 Promotion to First Nations, coaching and marketing will be able to be funded.

>$220 000 Construction to court #5 and #6 will take place and new tennis specific, energy efficient lights will be installed. 


The Impact


Our main goal is to get people more active, get families to do outdoor activities together and offer a secure tennis facility to the community. 

We had tremendous success during the past season in bringing school groups to the club during the spring. More than 150 children from as young as 6 years played tennis for the first time with this program.  We also had 78 children in summer camps this summer.

The majority of those campers have never played tennis before and almost 20 of them liked the sport enough to keep coming back to lessons and came to the club to play with their parents.  Many of these parents have not played tennis themselves since they were children.

Tennis can not survive in North Bay on courts that are in disrepair and are dangerous to play on. There are a small amount of public courts that people go and play on in North Bay.  There is no membership or marketing done to promote tennis on these courts and they are also used for other recreation activities like basketball and skateboarding.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to our cause, we know you know at least one person that plays tennis or used to play.  Please tell them about our club and about our fundraising. Please post our campaign on your Facebook page or Tweet about us. Any attention that we can draw to our site might help the future of tennis in the Nipissing District.

Other ways that you can help us is just by going out and playing tennis! When is the last time you played tennis? Dust off that racquet in the closet and go down to your local club and hit a few balls with a friend or your children.  There are now racquets and balls also that make tennis easier for even young children. 

Go and see where the closest courts are to you and go and try tennis out! Even if you choose not to support our courts, go and play tennis and see why it is one of the most popular sports in the world. You can play tennis from childhood all the way through to old age, its a great way to spend time with your family or friends and there are proven fitness benefits from the aerobic and anaerobic aspects of playing tennis.
story_txt: The Club and the CommunityThe Nipissing District Tennis Club is a seasonal tennis club in North Bay, Ontario with 6 courts and 246 members in 2013.  The club is owned by Fransua Rachmann and Bobby Ray. NDTC is the only tennis club in North Bay that offers a membership, programming, socials, leagues and tournaments.  We also offer tennis lessons for anyone from individual lessons to large school groups. In the summer we offer 8 weeks of summer camps for children between 7 and 17 years old.Bobby and Fransua only recently took over management of the courts. But the courts have not been resurfaced or properly maintained since 2007.  Of the 6 courts, 3 courts will be dangerous to play on next season.  Since North Bay is in Northern Ontario, it gets a lot of snow in the winter and the club only operate from April to October.  The big fluctuations in temperature causes the courts that were constructed more than 20 years ago to heave and crack.  Short term repairs have been attempted, but to make the courts safe and playable for the future, extensive reconstruction of the courts will have to be done.Contributors to the NDTC will help us deliver a service to more than 83000 people in North Bay and the Nipissing District.  A big part of the community are First Nations and with updated facilities we will be able to invite school groups and adults from the whole Nipissing District to introduce tennis to them and promote health and fitness.We would also like to make our facility more wheelchair accessible.  We need to convert part of our gravel parking lot and walkways into paved surface to accommodate wheelchairs.  We also need to convert our washrooms into wheelchair accessible units. Recently there has been a need for wheelchair access to the courts, and we want to meet those needs and also be able to promote wheelchair tennis in Northern Ontario.Our main goal is to introduce children to the game of tennis, have families play tennis together and to get people more active and fit. We want to break the notion of tennis being a "snobby" or "elite" sport and promote it as an affordable, fun activity for people of any age and all walks of life.Tennis is one of the few sports where a whole family can play together on one court, children and adults can keep a ball going over the net or play points against each other or parents can help their children practice coordination or hitting the ball.We offer tennis to people at very reasonable prices and people can even come and try tennis for free since they can borrow racquets and balls from the club at no cost.  We increased our membership from 172 members in the 2012 season (under previous management) to 246 members in 2013 and our next goal is to reach 275 members in 2014, but to make that possible we'll need all 6 courts to be in match play condition.Fransua and Bobby are the owners of Robert Fransua Inc. a sport management, coaching and event organising company. They became the owners of the Nipissing District Tennis Club in May 2013.Fransua has more than 15 years of coaching experience and has coached tennis in South Africa, the UK, USA and in the United Arab Emirates and now in Canada. He is one of only 125 coaches in Canada that has a Club Pro 2 Canadian Tennis Professional Association qualification. Fransua also has a Sport Psychology Diploma and a Business Management Diploma.Bobby Ray is a recent graduate of Nipissing University's Bachelor of Physical and Health Education program. Bobby is also the General Manager of the North Bay Granite Curling Club and volunteers with Sport North Bay and the local Young Professionals Committee.Why we need fundingFunding is needed for four areas at NDTC:1) Reconstruction of court 1, 2, 5 and 6.2 Resurfacing of court 3 and 43) Construction of wheelchair accessible walkways and washrooms4) Promotion and sponsorship of tennis to First Nations1) Court #1 currently has a crack running down the middle of it that is at certain places more than 2 inches wide and getting deeper with each rain fall. The crack is now spreading to court #2 and is getting to the point where the crack is not just affecting the bounce of the ball when it lands near the crack, but also starts being a tripping hazard to players. In places the crack is wide enough for a tennis shoe to fit into, if someone steps on the edge of this crack he or she might sprain or break an ankle.$80 000 will go towards demolition, lying a new foundation and then resurfacing of court #1 and #2Court #5 and #6 are the first courts that were built at the venue in 1960.  The courts were maintained and resurfaced numerous times over the years, but frost and heaving of the foundation has finally rendered these courts unfit for play.  The bumps and holes in the courts make bounces unpredictable and have caused people to trip on the courts. The lights on these courts are also outdated, inefficient and currently burned out bulbs that need to be replaced are not accessible. The posts used on these courts are higher than health and safety permit standard equipment to reach.  So a specialized crane will have to be rented every time a light bulb needs to be replaced.  Tennis specific lights with energy efficient bulbs will solve this problem.It will cost $110 000 to completely dig up these courts and replace the light posts.2) Court #3 and #4 are currently the only 2 courts that are in decent match playable shape.  But courts should ideally be resurfaced at least every 5 years and the last time that the courts were resurfaced was in 2007. Especially in regions where there are high fluctuations in temperature, keeping court surfaces in good shape seals the upper layers from water penetration.  Any water that seep into hairline cracks will freeze in the winter, expand and cause large fractures and bumps and dips on the court of the same nature as court #5 and #6.It will cost at least $20000 to resurface these two courts and insure their current condition for another 5 to 8 years3) Wheelchair accessibility is extremely important to give handicapped people in our region the opportunity to also experience playing tennis.  It is also important to us that our facility be accessible to handicapped spectators or family and friends of players.We have some walkways at the club at the moment and we also have a ramp that leads into our clubhouse.  But we have a gravel parking lot and a crushed rock path at one entrance and a grass patch at the other entrance that lead up to the walkways that make it extremely difficult for a wheelchair to reach the walkways.Our small washroom has also not been updated since the club has been established on the property in the 80's.  We have one unisex washroom with a toilet and a sink in a 5'x4' space.  We do have some space to expand and we need to convert some of our storage space into a larger washroom facility that is accessible for wheelchairs and provide a better looking and more comfortable washroom facility to our members and visitors to the club.Paving a small part of our parking lot will cost $6000 and expanding and updating the washroom will cost $120004) Providing services to First Nations in our area has been a long term goal for our company.  We have the opportunity to bring children to our facility and introduce them to tennis.  We also have the chance then to identify First Nation children with the drive and talent that might be interested in continuing lessons at the club and have the opportunity to compete in matches and tournaments at the club and in tournaments in Ontario.We also would like to market tennis to First Nations families as a fun activity that they can enjoy together to promote family values, fitness and recreation.With $12000 we'll be able to promote the sport, pay for transport to and from the club. and pay for lessons and equipment for at least two seasons at NDTC.   Plan BIf we don't get the desired amount of funding, we have to concentrate on the most important issues of the club in the following order.<$16 000 - The large crack on court #1 can get a short term fix by just concentrating on the crack itself and it can be sealed very cheaply at the beginning of each season. This will still cause an uneven bounce if balls do bounce anywhere along the fixed line, but the risk of people tripping and falling on the court is reduced. >$16 000 -  The other option is getting a tennis specific contractor to fix the crack.  The fix is guaranteed for 5 years and will cost more than $16000. >$30 000 The next issue is fixing and resurfacing court #2.>$60 000 Resurfacing court #3 and #4. This will guarantee the club has at least 4 new courts and the future of the club will be secure. The club will be able to pay for maintenance and resurfacing after every 5 years from membership and programming fees. Court #5 and #6 might need to be scrapped completely and not be used for tennis because of the tripping hazards on the court. The membership of the club might have to be capped at 250 members to accommodate all the players.  We will also not be able to host summer tennis camps on the courts since camps take up 2 courts in the summer for 8 weeks while members play at the same time on the other 4 courts.>$80 000) Wheelchair accessible parking lot, walkways and washrooms will be constructed>$100 000 Promotion to First Nations, coaching and marketing will be able to be funded.>$220 000 Construction to court #5 and #6 will take place and new tennis specific, energy efficient lights will be installed. The ImpactOur main goal is to get people more active, get families to do outdoor activities together and offer a secure tennis facility to the community. We had tremendous success during the past season in bringing school groups to the club during the spring. More than 150 children from as young as 6 years played tennis for the first time with this program.  We also had 78 children in summer camps this summer.The majority of those campers have never played tennis before and almost 20 of them liked the sport enough to keep coming back to lessons and came to the club to play with their parents.  Many of these parents have not played tennis themselves since they were children.Tennis can not survive in North Bay on courts that are in disrepair and are dangerous to play on. There are a small amount of public courts that people go and play on in North Bay.  There is no membership or marketing done to promote tennis on these courts and they are also used for other recreation activities like basketball and skateboarding.  Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't contribute to our cause, we know you know at least one person that plays tennis or used to play.  Please tell them about our club and about our fundraising. Please post our campaign on your Facebook page or Tweet about us. Any attention that we can draw to our site might help the future of tennis in the Nipissing District.Other ways that you can help us is just by going out and playing tennis! When is the last time you played tennis? Dust off that racquet in the closet and go down to your local club and hit a few balls with a friend or your children.  There are now racquets and balls also that make tennis easier for even young children. Go and see where the closest courts are to you and go and try tennis out! Even if you choose not to support our courts, go and play tennis and see why it is one of the most popular sports in the world. You can play tennis from childhood all the way through to old age, its a great way to spend time with your family or friends and there are proven fitness benefits from the aerobic and anaerobic aspects of playing tennis.

story:
Why Donate?

To contribute to the cause of helping Survivors recover from emotional and physical abuse. The debilitating consequences vary but often include flashbacks, anxiety, isolation, self-injury, and drug abuse, which may lead to death. 

  • Unification: Survivors and supporters (including experts in the field of Trauma and Dissociation) are all working together to provide survivors with a chance to recover and live a life worth living towards the goal of having available access to experienced clinicians. 
  • Advancement: Donations to this conference provide the necessary familiarity of successful treatments for survivors with the pysical and psychological effects of Trauma. 
  • Treatment: Your Donation will help distribute this unique experience and prospective for clinicians to treat their clients effectively and for survivors to confidently rely on professionals to properly treat the effects of Trauma. These survivors are actively seeking treatment and deserve properly trained professionals to successfully recover.  

What is Ivory Garden?

Ivory Garden operates as a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation in the United States that funds multiple forum sites, an informational website to promote awareness, community chat sessions, and educational webinars. IG helps connect both survivors and supporters to resources and tools to improve and save lives. 

  • Ivory Garden funds forums sites where survivors  and supporters (including health care professionals) are welcome to communicate. IG also funds private community scheduled member chats, 1 on 1 private peer support sessions with a trained peer supporter, and informational webinars  on many topics. 
  • The Ivory Garden DID support group is a survivor community of over 2,000 members from all around the world. All of them have a dissociative disorder and many have Dissociative Identity Disorder. 
  • The forum sites of Ivory Garden are moderated to maintain a safe and healing environment for recovery based on respect. 
  • The entire Ivory Garden staff are survivors of trauma and donate many hours of their time to ensure the community stays safe.  
  • Ivory Garden has never and never will charge a fee. IG does rely solely on donations. 


What good will a conference do?

This conference will focus on clinicians, child abuse survivors, and loved ones working together in order to share knowledge that will empower, enlighten, and benefit each uniquely. Our goal is that trauma survivors will leave the conference with the tools and knowledge that can be used in everyday life, that supporters acquire a better understanding of trauma and dissociation and its effects on survivors, and that clinicians gain skills that will be useful when treating dissociative and traumatized clients. 

 This conference has been approved by the Washington Chapter National Association of Social Workers (NASW) for Licensed Social Workers, Licensed Marriage & Family Therapists, and Licensed Mental Health Counselors (provider number  #1975-362)

  • Learn more on www.igdid.org about Topics and our expert speakers:
  • COLIN A. ROSS M.D.  
  • SANDRA L. PAULSEN, Ph.D. 
  • JOAN C. GOLSTON, DCSW, LICSW
  • DAVID L. CALOF
  • MARVIN THOMAS, Therapist, Teacher, Community Expert
  • LAURA S. BROWN, Ph.D
  • LYNN CROOK, M.Ed.,
  • GINA VANCE, CLC, CMHT, CCHT, RBT
  • ELLIE FIELDS, LPC, LIMHP, CPC
  • SUSAN PEASE BANITT, LCSW, RYT


Can I go to the conference?

Yes! Ivory Garden warmly welcomes everyone to attend! Attendance is limited to 350 individuals. You'll find all the current details on the conference website:  http://www.igdid.org    

  • The 2014 Trauma and Dissociation Conference will be held in Seattle, Washington at the Double Tree Hilton at Sea-Tac from Friday, October 3rd through Sunday, October 5th. 
  • There will be a Survivor Art Show, an Ivory Garden Spirit Items, a sight-seeing tour, books by our speakers and other sponsors, and much more!
  • We welcome your questions or comments! Please email Felicity4us2@gmail.com

How else can I help?

  • Please talk about the conference to anyone who might be interested. Use the indegogo share buttons and check out our websites. Ivory Garden is on Facebook, Tumblr, Twitter, and YouTube!
  • We need volunteers for the conference- no experience required. Please email Felicity4us2@gmail.com or glasscastle.ivorygarden@gmail.com
  • Print out the Brochure and share it at coffee shops, hospitals, clinics, and any community resource boards at grocery stores, libraries, ect. 
  • We would also love items to sell on our site via auction. For more information please email: glasscastle.ivorygarden@gmail.com


Thank you for supporting Survivors around The Globe by helping Ivory Garden!

story:
My name is Mike Liberto, and I am an MMA fighter, professional boxer, and next season I will follow in my stepfather's footsteps and become a wrestling coach at Bethlehem Catholic High School. I would like to help the team by funding a scholarship for a wrestlers in my stepfather's name.

Every athlete has someone in their life who encourages them every step of the way. For me, that person was my stepfather, John Fenstermacher. As a high school wrestling coach he really fostered my love of the sport and encouraged me to become a professional athlete. He always put his students first and emphasized academics. I will continue this tradition.

Every little bit counts. Supporters that contribute $50 and up will get a private training session with me, the Bethlehem Brawler!

Even if you can't provide financial support, please help spread the word and share the campaign. Thank you!

story:
No more boring running.
Sound blockbuster for running, TRACKS! 

Same music, same roads…
And that’s how you’ve stopped running.

Introducing a new way of running with TRACKS app 
where stories lead how you run.


  • Check out our story in detail on TheNextWeb




TRACKS is not my first running app with RPG elements that I’ve used, but it’s the first app to successfully scared the crap out of me. The sounds were so realistic — having a good pair of earphones is not helping at all! — I actually caught myself looking back while running. Especially since I tried the first chapter at 11:30pm. Not even the zombie version was as scary. I highly suggest runners to NOT run with TRACKS at night. Unless you’re a horror fan, then you would probably enjoy it a lot.

ALSON KAW
Creative Director @ Caffein8 Creative LABS





Ready to run?
Lace up your runner and open up TRACKS.
The platoon and growlers are waiting for you.




Step 1. Plug in your earbuds.
Step 2. Select an episode.
Step 3. Run and complete all missions.
Step 4. Check out your run results and ranking.




INTRO


Growler...
Although they take the shape of humans,
the Growlers are over 2 meters tall, wrapped in bandages, and black. They react to sound and heat,  as well as hunt humans.

The Growlers are chasing, the buildings are collapsing.
Avoid all shells falling from the skies.

 The road you run becomes an action film scene with total 15 episodes of Growler series. The episodes present a variety of missions featuring sessions of sprints, shocking, intervals, and more of the most efficient 10 types of running.


SOUND EQUAL TO A BLOCKBUSTER FILM


Our focus was on creating the most realistic in-app sounds to make sure you run.


   POINT 1. Same sound production process as foley



 Realism is the foundation of TRACKS. 
 TRACKS’s main focus is to make scenes come true in runners’ minds without the visuals. To achieve this, we used the same workflow as the film makers, foley. TRACKS is an experience beyond audiobooks.

 Imagination was evident in our sound design stages in order to make all scenes as realistic as possible. Each scene and movement in our visualizations were recreated with sound that we believe would happen.

 Imagine a scene where growlers invade an army base from the ceiling. As the glass and the lights come crashing down, all background noise except the cracking sounds are eliminated. We then play the collapsing sound in reverse to create higher tension followed by a soundless void that gets you to stop and listen.

 When the growlers enter the scene, they come in with the whoosh sound in the background. Detailed sounds from their entrance like the falling debris and the cracking of the stone floor are layered to showcase the growlers’ landing movements.



 Find the final product of all combined sounds we’ve mentioned above here.
Test out our sound and jump into the scene itself.

As if you are watching a film,
feel the surround sound from the growlers chasing,
feel the gunshot whizzing by your ears,
but you only need your earphones.

TRACKS, your sound blockbuster. 



   POINT 2. Run, as if you are watching a film.

 Growlers’ sounds are all created with “Dehumanizer Pro” for its high quality. Dehumanizer is used to create sounds for Marvel’s “Avengers: AGE OF ULTRON” and the upcoming Disney film, “THE JUNGLE BOOK”.



< Dehumaniser >

Dehumaniser is a vocal processing software that can create realistic monster sounds in real time. It does not utilize samples and therefore designs a situation-specific sound.



   POINT 3. TRY TRACKS NOW!

 We recommend you to open up our first episode, “GROWLER” in the early evening when the sun sets and the dark night begins. 
Let your body listen, feel, and react to the growlers chasing after you.



RUN! GET THE MOST HONORABLE RANK.

 After you accomplished each chapter, your personal running data and rank will be recorded on a Daily Feed. You can easily access not only your today's data but the amount of yours.

 Our rank system is divided as six levels including hidden class. You will get a rank called The Evidence Finder as a beginner.

 As you accomplish your chapters and gain more points, you can get a higher rank like The Secret Spy, The Demolition Expert, etc. Also there is a hidden class you can't get if you're challenge your limits and get a most honorable rank, The Growler Annihilator. 
Rank up and be one of the leading lights in the defense force.



  • Those who want to beat running boredom.

  • Those who love jogging or running.

  • Those who are training for marathon more fun.

  • Those who want to run efficiently.

  • A Voice actor or voiceover artist. Or who want to be!

  • Even those who want to enjoy a sound from your speakers. lol




$10,000 USD Achieved.
If we reach $10,000 there will be one extra Basic Membership Coupon for every single Backers who got more than $5 perk.
Fight against the Growlers with your friends!






KEEP FOLLOWING OUR STORY

Don't miss out! Get updated with TRACKS.
● Visit our website
● Follow us on Twitter
● Like us on Facebook

THANK YOU! We cannot wait for making sure you run.
Check out our limited perk and be the first one who meet GROWLER!
Are you interested in a sound advertisement or B2B Plan?
Don't hesitate to contact us with unsolicited services or offers!

Are you interested in Tracks? Here's TRACKS press kit. 
If you have any questions you can always reach out to us contact@tracks.today


FAQ 


FAQ is updated during crowdfunding period. If you have any questions, don't hesitate! 

1. When TRACKS App is available? 

Tracks App is almost developed and It will be available in end of JUNE 2016! 
It will be available at Appstore and GooglePlayMarket. 
Thank you for your interest and please wait a little time! 


2. When the beta testing program start?
Tracks' beta testing program starts in this weekend.
We'll send all contributors an invitation mail, please wait a little more!

FAQ 
FAQ is updated during crowdfunding period. If you have any questions, don't hesitate! 


1. When TRACKS App is available? Tracks App is almost developed and It will be available in end of JUNE 2016! It will be available at Appstore and GooglePlayMarket. Thank you for your interest and please wait a little time! 


2. When the beta testing program start?
Tracks' beta testing program starts in this weekend.We'll send all contributors an invitation mail, please wait a little more!

story:
Lazer Sauce @ Burning Man 2016

Sup doe? We're Camp Lazer Brigade!

For those who haven't heard of us, we're a Burning Man theme camp based out of Denver, Colorado. For the past 3 years, we've rescued over 1500 people from bland food on the Playa. Beyond our delicious Lazer Sauce, we're providing awesome events & services to the Burning Man community like drop-in bike repairs, Bourbon tasting, & home brewed beer. This year, we'd really like to kick up what we can offer to our fellow burners, so help us cover the costs!

What's this all about?

  • We need peppers. Lots of them. HUNDREDS OF NATURE'S SPICIEST PEPPERS
  • When you contribute, not only will you receive a bottle of Lazer Sauce, but you'll be providing a bottle for someone eating some sad, bland mac & cheese on the Playa
  • Our goal is to make & bottle 500 week-sized portions of Lazer Sauce for this year's burn. Any extra money raised from this will go directly to our camp's events. Events like Tequila Tasting Putt Putt, the Cropstacle Course, & our Beer & Hip Hop party. 

Why raise money?

We've brought Lazer Sauce for the last three years, why raise money now? 

Great question! We've made a ton of friends in the Burning Man community with our sauce. Everyone seems to get pretty depressed a few weeks after the Burn when their sauce runs out and asks us where they can get more. Why not give the people what they want, while allowing us to make more to share with the community and put on even better events along the way?

Every dollar raised will go directly into providing sauce for the community and putting on better events!

story:
Version Español

The Route: We will begin the trip in early 2016 from Guatemala. We will make our way through Central and South America, visiting about 2 communities per country.

Follow our journey www.facebook/caminocasamel

Aidan & Johanna

Aidan: I'm a General Doctor who enjoys being spontaneous, doing new things, exploring, making a difference and showing the world it is possible to do things differently. I'm Guatemala and I feel the Latin American blood that runs through my veins very strongly.

Johanna: I'm an American-German-Venezuelan who dreams of a border-less world. For the last few years, I have been working on the community level with various environmental projects in Caracas, Venezuela. From these experiences stems my passion to creatively discover and share about more sustainable ways of living in balance with nature and people.


What We Need & What You Get

We've purchased the van for our trip. Now we need $8,000 to begin the expedition! These costs are for adapting the van to work with waste-vegetable-oil, buying a centrifuge for filtering the oil, converting the van into a house-car, and expenses for our first 3  months of the trip.

Here is our cost breakdown:

Get our book

Upon completion of the journey, all of our supporters who contribute with +$25 will receive an e-book documenting all of our findings. For those who support us with a hundred-dollar donation, or more, we will send you a printed and signed copy of the book!

The book will contain everything we learn from ancient medicinal practices to local indigenous customs that the majority of us in the industrialized world have forgotten. We will also feature anecdotes from the people who share these experiences with us. 

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will use the amount raised towards adapting the car to work with waste-vegetable-oil and then towards converting it into a house-car.


What we want to learn:

  • Natural Medicine: Compile botanical and ancient health knowledge from each region
  • Health and environmental impact of changing life styles: Gain an in-depth understanding of the causes and consequences of globalization’s consumer trends and how it effects on the lifestyle of these small isolated communities.
  • Agro-Ecology: Learn more about alternative farming methods with hands-on experience and learn more about how conventional farming is affecting the health and environments of local populations


What we will do

As we are going to visit rural communities learning about natural medicine, we will also provide preventative medical attention and do recycling projects because we believe it’s important to have a mutual exchange with the people we get to know.

Aidan, the Doctor, will provide Health Care: Sharing knowledge about how to prevent and treat common illnesses and local health-related issues. Aidan will also provide emergency medical attention such as attending births, caring for cuts and injuries, detecting malnutrition and other medical emergencies.

Johanna will lead Recycling Projects: some examples are a bottle cap mural, shoes and garden decoration with tires, crafts with junk food wrappers, construction with plastic bottles, and more.


How will we find the communities we visit?

We will use two main avenues for connecting with rural communities:
1. Prior connections: We are connected to many individuals, social projects and NGOs throughout Latin America. Through this network we will find out about and be directed towards various communities. As we travel, we also hope to get connect to more people and communities.

2. Random: Since we don't have prior connections in all the countries we hope to visit, we will also select some communities 'randomly' with as much research and preparation as possible from nationals in the country.

Other Ways You Can Help

Our project is mainly sustained by donors interested in supporting research and donors with generous hearts who believe in our cause!

Here are some other ways to support Camino Casamel:

1. Share our campaign page and promo-video through social media and with people that may be interested in supporting us!

2. Commit to supporting us monthly with $10, $25 or $50. These funds will go towards replenishing medical supplies, border crossing fees and other important expenses that arise as we are on our trip. Contact us at caminocasamel@gmail.com to learn more.

3. We are exploring products we can create and sell, such as natural soaps made with vegetable oil. We would love to hear any ideas you may have. 



Waste Vegetable Oil (WVO) Fuel

Why will we travel with Waste Vegetable Oil (WVO)?

One of our main purposes in traveling through Latin America is to learn and share knowledge about health and environmental care in the communities we visit. Therefore, we would like our transportation method to be as environmentally friendly as possible. In Latin America, there aren’t many sources of ‘clean energy’ for cars, especially not easily accessible for the general public. After researching more about the topic, we decided this was the most accessible form of clean energy for us.

What are the advantages of using this type of alternative fuel?

First, we will recycle thousands of gallons of used kitchen oil that would otherwise be poured down the drain, polluting water and soil because there is no system to adequately dispose the oil in Latin America. Secondly, WVO fuel is 100% renewable. We will most likely travel over 15,000 kilometers. Think about all the CO2 we won’t be releasing into the atmosphere! Lastly, WVO is free.  This means saving on gas money during the trip.  

How will we obtain WVO as we travel?

We will ask restaurants and hotels that deep fry for their used oil (Asian restaurants, for example).

How do WVO vehicles work?

To run on WVO, the vehicle must be diesel, preferably between the years 1985 and 2002. Our van is a 1987 E350 Ford. We will use a 2-tank system, one for diesel and the other for the WVO. We will buy a conversion kits to adapt our car to work with WVO. Once the vehicle is converted, the car will turn on with the diesel fuel and once it is hot, we will switch it to the WVO fuel. To turn the car off, we'll switch back to diesel. Additionally, the vegetable oil needs to be filtered before it can be used. We will use a centrifuge for filtering. For more in depth information, visit:www.wvodesigns.com/wiki/Main_Page


Español


La Ruta: Empezaremos a principios del 2016 desde Guatemala.Viajaremos por Centroamérica y Sudamérica, visitando aproximadamente 2 comunidades por pais.

Siguenos en www.facebook.com/caminocasamel

Aidan  y Johanna

Aidan: Soy Medico General, me gusta ser espontáneo, reinventar, explorar y sobre todo marcar la diferencia y demostrarle al mundo que se pueden hacer las cosas distintas.  Soy de Guatemala y en mis venas corre la sangre de  América Latina. 

Johanna: Soy una Gringa-Alemana-Venezolana que sueña con un mundo sin fronteras. Durante los últimos años, he trabajando en varios proyectos ambientales a nivel comunitario en Caracas, Venezuela. De estas experiencias surge mi pasión de creativamente descubrir y compartir maneras mas sustentables de vivir, con mayor equilibrio con la naturaleza y las personas.

 

Lo que necesitamos y lo que tu recibiras

Ya compramos la van para el viaje. Ahora necesitamos $8,000 para empezar la expedición, estos costos son para adaptar la van para que funcione con aceite vegetal usado, comprar una centrifugadora para filtrar el aceite, convertir la van en un casa-carro y los costos para los primeros 3 meses del viaje.


Obten nuestro libro

Al terminar el viaje, todos nuestros apoyadores recibirán un libro electronico con todos nuestros encuentros, especificamente de medicina natural y formas mas sostenibles de vivir. Para los que nos apoyan con una donación de $100 o mas, les daremos una copia impresa y firmada del libro.

Todo lo que aprenderemos será recopilado en el libro, este incluirA temas como practicas ancestrales de medicina y tradiciones indígenas locales que la mayoría de nosotro en el mundo industrializado hemos dejado atras, destacando anecdotas de las personas que nos comparten estas experiencias.

Lo que queremos aprender:

  • Medicina Natural: Conocer, observar y aprender de los métodos de medicina natural y conocimientos de salud ancestrales de cada region, y así ampliar los conocimientos en medicina natural y darlos a conocer a personas quienes nos apoyan.

  • Efectos locales de salud y ambiente por estilos de vida cambiantes: Observar más a fondo las causas y consecuencias en los cambios de patrones de consumo y estilo de vida en las comunidades rurales por la globalización y los efectos que conllevan estas acciones.

  • Agroecología: Conocer a través de la práctica métodos alternativos de siembra y aprender mas a fondo como la siembra convencional afecta la salud y el ambiente local del agricultor.


Lo que Haremos

Durante el viaje cuando visitemos comunidades rurales aprendiendo acerca de medicina natural, daremos atención médica preventiva y haremos proyectos de reciclaje porque creemos que es importante tener un intercambio mutuo con las personas que conocemos.

Aidan, el doctor, dara atencion medica: Compartiendo informacion de como prevenir y tratar enfermedades comunes y temas de salud local. Aidan también proveerá atención médica emergente, como por ejemplo atención de partos, curar heridas y lesiones, detección de malnutrición.

Johanna hara proyectos de reciclaje:  Mural con tapitas de botellas plásticas (u otro tipo de material reusable), zapatos y objetos para jardinería elaborados con cauchos (llantas), manualidades con plastico de comida chatarra (chuchería), compost (creando abono natural), entre otros.



Otras Formas de Apoyarnos

Nuestro proyecto se sostiene principalmente por donaciones por personas interesadas en nuestras investigaciones de medicina natural y por personas con corazones generosas que creen en nuestra causa.

Hay varias maneras que nos puedes apoyar:

  1. COMPARTE nuestra campaña y el video promocional en tus redes sociales y con personas que puedan estar interesados en el proyecto.

  2. Considera apoyarnos mensualmente, estas donaciones serán usadas para reponer materiales médicos, impuestos en las fronteras, y otros gastos que puedan surgir en el camino. Contactanos en caminocasamel@gmail.com para aprender mas.

  3. Estamos explorando la opción de crear y vender productos para generar ingresos en el trayecto, como por ejemplo crear jabónes natural a base de aceite vegetal. Si tienes alguna idea háganoslo saber.

Aceite Vegetal como Combustible

¿Porque Viajaremos con Aceite Vegetal Usado (WVO)?

Gran parte de nuestro objetivo viajando por Latinoamérica es poder aprender y compartir nuestros saberes de salud y ambiente en las comunidades que visitemos. Por lo tanto queremos que nuestro método de transporte sea, dentro de lo posible, con ‘Energía Limpia.’ En Latinoamérica no existen muchas fuentes de energía renovable para carros, sobre todo al alcance del público. Despues de investigar mas el tema, decidimos que esta era la mejor opción para nosotros.

¿Cuales son las ventajas de este combustible alternativo?

Primeramente, reciclaremos cientos de litros de aceite usado que de manera contraria serían agentes contaminantes en el agua y los suelos, ya que la mayor parte de Latino America no tiene sistema adecuada para desechar este material. Ademas, este combustible es 100% renovable y gratis. Viajaremos mas que 15,000 kilometros. ¡Imaginate todo el dióxido de carbono que nos salvamos de contaminar! Por ultimo, WVO es gratis, lo que implica un gran ahorro de gastos en combustible.  

¿Cómo obtendremos el WVO mientras viajamos?

Le pediremos a restaurantes  y hoteles en el camino por su aceite vegetal usado, como por ejemplo a restaurantes asiaticos o locales que usan mucho aceite para freír.

¿Cómo funciona un vehículo con aceite vegetal usado (WVO)?

Para que un carro funcione con WVO, ESTE debe ser diesel, preferiblemente entre los años 1985 y 2002.  Nuestra van es un Ford E350 del anio 1987. Utilizaremos un sistema de doble tanque. Compraremos un ‘kit’ para adaptar nuestro carro para que funcione con aceite vegetal. Despues de realizar esta conversion,  el carro se encenderA con combustible de diesel y cuando esta caliente lo cambiaremos es preferible de manera que un tanque sea para el diesel y el otro para el WVO. Siempre se debe filtrar el aceite vegetal antes de usarlo. Cuando el vehículo esté ya adaptado, el carro se enciende con combustible diesel, después de que esté caliente se cambia al tanque de combustible WVO. De igual manera para apagarlo, uno lo cambia a diesel. Para mas informacion visite: www.wvodesigns.com/wiki/Main_Page

story:
https://www.facebook.com/letshelpkalimantan

Summary

Imagine PSI 1980, and imagine the helplessness of a people powerless against the injustice in their land. Singaporeans, let's help Kalimantan.

It breaks out hearts to hear, see and read the stories on the ground. When we think of the PSI 1980, we think of the roadside vendor who has no choice but to continue to sell drinks in the thick polluted air; we think of the motorists who run into fatal accidents because of the terrible visibility; we think of the innocent children running around without any protection; we think of the elderly people struggling to breathe; we think of the young people storming their governor's gate, furiously breathless at the injustice in their land; we think of a people too poor to afford N95 masks, and too helpless, too vulnerable.

What You & I Can Do 

Our Facebook page outlines our Collection Dates: 24 & 26 September 2015, where we welcome donations of N95 masks -- both standard sized ones (buy these from hospitals, Guardian pharmacy, Unity Pharmacy) & small child-sized ones (buy those from Watson's). 

Our raised funds would go first toward fast shipping costs, with the remainder used to buy as many N95 masks that we can. 

**If we are able to get sponsorships from DHL to cover shipping costs, we will use the raised funds for the purchase of more N95 masks (especially children masks). 3M & DHL - ARE YOU  READING THIS? :) 

The Impact

To ensure impact, we are in contact with WALHI Indonesia, Planet Indonesia, as well as few other activists on the ground, who will help in the distribution to poor neighbourhoods, schools, and the far-flung areas. 

http://www.walhi.or.id/

http://www.planetindonesia.org/

To ensure transparency, all receipts will be posted on our FB page, with photos of our Indonesian distribution.


Risks & Challenges

If we don't raise enough funds to cover shipping, we will break our piggy banks and cover the costs ourselves. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share our FB page! Please tell your friends! 

    https://www.facebook.com/letshelpkalimantan

  • Understand the impact of our shopping habits:  https://webreathewhatwebuy.com/index.php/haze/

Let's do this, Singapore!
story_txt:
https://www.facebook.com/letshelpkalimantan
Summary Imagine PSI 1980, and imagine the helplessness of a people powerless against the injustice in their land. Singaporeans, let's help Kalimantan. It breaks out hearts to hear, see and read the stories on the ground. When we think of the PSI 1980, we think of the roadside vendor who has no choice but to continue to sell drinks in the thick polluted air; we think of the motorists who run into fatal accidents because of the terrible visibility; we think of the innocent children running around without any protection; we think of the elderly people struggling to breathe; we think of the young people storming their governor's gate, furiously breathless at the injustice in their land; we think of a people too poor to afford N95 masks, and too helpless, too vulnerable.  What You & I Can Do  Our Facebook page outlines our Collection Dates: 24 & 26 September 2015, where we welcome donations of N95 masks -- both standard sized ones (buy these from hospitals, Guardian pharmacy, Unity Pharmacy) & small child-sized ones (buy those from Watson's). 
Our raised funds would go first toward fast shipping costs, with the remainder used to buy as many N95 masks that we can.

story:
My Campaign 

    My name is Staci Spearn I was a normal college junior and one day in class everything changed. I felt like I couldn't breath, talk, and I was very itchy. I went to the nurse and she said I was having an allergic reaction. Never having one before I panicked, that's how it all started. This continued for a year with the help of steroids I did well I thought. But on November 7, 2012 everything I thought I knew went out the window when I went into anaphylactic shock. These means that my throat was closing and despite the help of the doctors and nurses they couldn't stop it with the normal drugs. The had to intubate me to stop my throat from swelling shut. I was in a medically induced  coma  for five days. When I woke up I didn't know where I was, what had happened, or what day it was. At this time I was just months away from graduating from college; I had plans for after graduation, places I wanted to go, and what I wanted to do with my life. All of those plans went out the window, while I was trying to cope with losing all my plans, I was also trying to figure out how I was going to pay back college, pay for my medical bills, and live everyday without fear. It didn't work.. The bills kept coming and eventually I couldn't do it any more. 

    I'm tired of taking 7 pills twice a day so I can go outside of my house. Most days I find it hard to get out of bed, despite all of this I have managed to work two jobs without another incident for three months, however the bills don't stop and I have calculated my total of hospital and doctors bills to just over 20,000 dollars. By donating the this your helping me pay for the doctors, hospitals, and days I miss work because of these allergies. Along with those bills I have bills for my councilor that helps me cope with my PTSD from November and helps me realize I can go out to the movies and that I shouldn't be afraid. I don't ask for attention on social media and I've rarely asked for any help but my family and I can't afford groceries half the time and it's time to ask for help. 

    I can't give you anything in return the only thing I can give is my thanks and prayers for your well being. Your support will help me but will also help other to realize it's ok to say your struggling, it's ok to ask for help, and it's ok to be vulnerable and open with your health conditions. 

What We Need & What You Get

    I need $15,000 to pay off my bill at Floyd Valley Hospital, I need $4,000 to pay off doctors at the local doctors office and at Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Mn. I can not in words say what it would mean to be able to afford or feel safe going to vacation. I feel that without help I could never get out from under all of this medical debit. Through all of the sever reactions I've had over the last 3 years I have not once gone after any of the people who were responsible for sending me to the hospital, or the people who are/were responsible for all of the medical bills. 
    I'm the kind of person that believes in forgiveness and compassion towards others. I know that most people would take some of these people for everything they have but that's not the person I am nor the person I want to be. When I'm gone from this world I want people to remember that I was forgiving, trustworthy, and honest. These are all things I value in other people and I believe that you have to put good out to get good back!
    Even if we don't reach our goal every dollar will go to helping me and my family Pu for my medical bills. I would make sure that very cent received is towards helping me afford this medical condition that is untreatable. I want everyone to know about food allergies and that they are a big deal. I hear people on planes complaining about not getting peanuts or something but here's the thing those nuts, that you really don't need, could mean death or something very close to it for me and many others. 
    Although peanuts are not my only allergy they are a major one. The top five things that even being around that will send me to the hospital are: Jalapeños, Hot Sauce, Peanuts, All Peppers, and Perfumes. All of these things cause face, lip, and tongue swelling making it hard to go out to normal places. Even the slightest taste of any of these things will put me into anaphylactic shock again. The slightest contact and boom your day is ruined and you life could be over. I hope that you can see how your actions directly effect my life and how that could be changeling to deal with. 

The Impact

    The impact your contribution will make will be endless. If all this post gets is awareness for people suffering with food allergies I will be happy. If this post gets even $25 it will mean that's one more step in the right direction! 

With every donation I will be one more step closer to paying for the medical bills I have now. And with very dollars earned over the goal amount I will be one step closer to being able to pay future medical bills. When your in the hospital as much as I am the smallest amounts help. When I'm missing work and accruing cost it's hard to catch up on bills and it's hard to keep up with the payments.  

Risks & Challenges

   There aren't any guarantees I can give you. Why? Because tomorrow isn't a guarantee. I don't know how long I will live with these sever allergies before it over takes me. Many young people die from sever allergies and it's challenging to help them all but the smallest of acts can make the difference between life and death. I know this first hand and I can only hope that we can get the help we need and that everyone with food allergies can get the understanding they deserve.  

Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can't contribute financially you can like and share this. The more people see this the more people can help. Let your friends know, tell your neighbor, tell your family, or just share it on social media. The more people know about food allergies (not just mine) and how sever they can get the more people will support people with food allergies. People with food allergies need your support and need you help to spread awareness.

story:
Help me get back to acting

 Burbank, California, United States  Health

My name is Walter Olkewicz and I've had the good fortune to be an actor for the past 40 years. I've done some 50 movies and over a 100 TV shows. That ended about 15 years ago with my first knee surgery. Infections cropped up over and over again to the tune of, to date, 19 surgeries and my living in a wheel chair the past ten years. Recently I was introduced to a doctor from Mexico who'd had great results with the treatment of infections. The shots I was given have been working and according to my surgeon the infections have been subsiding. The prayers of friends and family were finally answered. 

The only problem is the injections and the care I've needed to continue- none of this is covered by insurance. I've depleted all of my savings and I simply can not afford to continue without help. Before this treatment started my doctor spoke of the very real possibility of having my leg amputated. Needless to say, this scared the bejesus out of me. After so many surgeries and this most welcome recent success, I simply can not even imagine not continuing. 

Please Help!

  **** I'd like at this point to thank all who have helped. As most of you know this is the 2nd half of a campaign that started a couple of months ago. Although I only reached a bit less than 40% of my goal (explaining the need for this campaign), I have begun the treatments and have increased their frequency 200%!! The results are miraculous! Talk of amputation is at this point off the table. Though still a possibility it has gone from a 50/50 chance to less than a 5% chance. I can breathe easier. But now I need to complete the program which will reach into about a 6 month total. The shots both eradicate the infection AND (the more important part right now) build the cells and revive a leg that hasn't been used much in the past 12-15 years. Two months ago it was like trying to walk on a wet noodle. As my leg builds strength (currently at bread stick status), it will eventually- with a shipload of hard work- return to most of the strength I had in the leg 20 years ago.  Part of my "Goal" calculations include work with a physical trainer. Luckily some of that IS covered by insurance. Insurance covers 8 times per 3-month period, I need work with a trainer 5+ times a week.Not an easy path, but one I can dedicate myself to. Thanks to all of you.

Over the first 30 years of my blessed career I was known for helping people (In the ten years that I ran my theater- The Jewel Box- over half of my students were there on "Scholarships" because they simply could not afford to come to class otherwise). I have coached fellow actors, people on the set, pretty much anybody I was lucky enough to work with for free, just trying to give back some of the good fortune I'd been lucky enough to receive. 

Now I find it time to ask for help. 

The estimated cost of these injections, the travel involved with obtaining them, and the personal care I need in the time until I am walking and "on my feet" again is about fifty thousand dollars (that figure might seem high until you consider that the hospital and doctor bills that were covered by insurance is nearly half a million)

True "Hope" is finally in my heart again. And being the creative animal that I am thoughts for a new theater keep me awake at night. I will make it happen! You can't imagine how frustrating something like persistent knee infections can be in blocking this dream. It would be like Picasso not being able to paint because he is in court fighting overdue traffic tickets. Okay, it's not exactly the same but you get the idea. 

Over the past few years I have had lots of hospital time to read and study the great spiritual thinkers. I've come to understand that my ideas for an uplifting, inspiring theater are a direct result of me connecting with my Divine Purpose. I don't want that to sound egotistical or "highfalutin", you see each of us has a Divine Purpose. I've just been lucky enough to finally understand mine.  

So anyone generous enough to contribute, I will gladly include you in our opening audience at "Up On Stage", my new theater. 

Sooo....

Anybody who contributes $25  gets an autographed picture of me from whatever work of mine they most like (or a copy of my knee X-rays if you are goofy enough for that to be more appealing to you). I apologize for the levity, but I learned a while ago that if I can't laugh at all this I am in real trouble. 

For $50 dollars you will get four tickets to my first weeks opening - copies of my knee X-rays will be distributed at the door. 

And for a $100 dollars or more you will get an autograph picture, four tickets to opening week, and my son will come over and mow your lawn.  Okay he is probably too busy to do that. If you call me I'll give you my advice on how to make your lawn greener by using paper machete mulch. 

Thank you very much for even reading this request. Please understand that despite any frivolity this is a most serious situation. My life and future career depend on it. 

Financial times being what they are, if you can't contribute yourself, I hope you will be willing to spread the word of my situation to your personal contacts. I believe we are all here on this planet to help each other. I hope you agree. And I hope you will consider my plight worthy of your generosity. If not my prayers are with you for wherever your generosity might flow.

story:
Hi, my name is Jack. 

I'm 10 years old.  I've been growing my hair out for over a year and 1/2 for Cuts for Cancer. I started with a mohawk, so it took me a really long time to grow my hair.
I'm going to shave my head soon and send it along with any money I raise to Cuts for Cancer. I wanted to grow my hair to help other kids, who are sick feel better.  
Help make it stop!
If you want to donate some money to help stop kids from getting cancer, it would be awesome.  
Also - if you want to join me in my #shaveforthebrave campaign, you can check out this site for more info!
Thanks for watching my video and donating!
<3 Jack
